system.description:
General

Detect magic creates a tunnel of magical vision in a path ten ft wide and thirty ft long, in which the druid sees the aura of any magic item as a glowing blue nimbus.

The druid can only scan a 60° arc during the course of a round: turning more quickly does not allow magic auras enough time to form in the druid's vision.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell's effect is blocked by solid wood 3 ft thick, by stone 1 ft thick, and by solid metal 1 inch thick.

actions.name: Detect Magic
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target the caster and click the "Detecting Magic - Duration (C)" action

system.description:
General

The druid may cast this spell upon herself, imbuing her eyes with divinatory power. The druid can instantly discern virtually any form of trap if outdoors, and even indoors or underground she will detect the presence of pits.

actions.name: Detect Pits and Snares
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done).
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target the caster and click the  "Detect Pits/Snares - Duration (C)" action

system.description:
General

The druid uses this spell to ignite a fiery-looking aura of bright light around his or her enemies. The aura is visible at a range of 80 ft if the observer stands in darkness, and at 40 ft if he or she stands near another light source.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

There isn't any saving throw against the spell's effects.

 

Combat Effects

The light itself is harmless, but a creature limned with faerie fire is easier to hit; any attacks against it are made with a bonus of +2.

actions.name: Faerie Fire
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have occurred)
  • Target the caster's selection of actors in the AOE and click the  "Faerie Fire - Duration (T)" action to apply the light effect to the selected actors

system.areaOfEffect: 1 size M or 2 size S creatures/level

system.description:
General

The Animal Friendship spell enchants a normal animal of neutral alignment to become the druid's faithful friend and companion.

Once the spell is complete, the animal will remain with the druid and can learn tricks similar to those that could be taught to a well-trained domestic pet. Each trick takes a week to learn, and after the animal has been with the druid for three months it will no longer be able to learn new tricks.

During this period, if the animal is left alone by the druid for more than three days, the enchantment will be broken and the animal will revert to the wild.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

If the animal fails its saving throw (made at the beginning of the spell's casting), it will remain docile for the remainder of the casting time.

The animal to be enchanted must not be completely unintelligent but cannot be of greater than animal intelligence.

A druid may only have animal friends with hit dice totalling twice his or her level. (The total hit dice can thus increase as the druid gains levels.)

system.description:
General

This spell allows the druid to speak with all animals of a particular type or species that are within 40 ft of him or her when the spell's casting is complete. In all other respects, except as denoted above, the spell is identical to the second level cleric spell Speak With Animals.

 

REFERENCED TEXT: 

When the caster invokes this spell, he or she becomes able to communicate with and understand the "speech" of normal animals (with the exception of mindless creatures).

 

Saves and Other Impediments

It is important to note that the spell does not permit speech with animals of monstrous or unnatural nature; communication with a monster such as a cockatrice, for example, is beyond the spell's power.

Neither does the spell suddenly imbue an animal with intelligence; the observations and opinions of an animal such as a badger will be appropriate to the animal's own experiences, motives, and intellectual limitations.

 

Combat Effects

While the spell lasts, the animal (and any other animals of the same type in its company) will refrain from attacking, even if they were initially hostile.

Depending upon the nature of the conversation, if the animal's alignment is neutral or of the same tendency as the cleric's, the animal may be disposed to help the cleric in some manner.

actions.name: Speak with Animals
actions.description:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the caster and click the "Speaking with Animals - Duration (C)" action

system.areaOfEffect: One creature within 40 ft of the caster

system.description:
General

The druid casts this spell upon a particular spot, whereupon all plants in a 20 ft radius of the enchanted location immediately begin to writhe violently about, whipping around and entangling any creature in the area.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

Creatures threatened in this manner are entitled to a saving throw.

 

Combat Effects

If the saving throw succeeds, the creature's movement rate is slowed to half normal.

If the saving throw fails, the creature is so securely held in the plants that it cannot move, attack, or cast spells for the duration of the spell.

[Although not specified in the spell, a common house rule is to allow those entangled to be attacked as follows:

  • slain if immobile and reachable with a melee weapon
  • attacked as if stunned (no dex, no shield, +4 to hit) if immobile and missile weapons are required to attack

- Ed.]

actions.name: Entangle
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • (Optional) Use the castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target all actors in the AOE and cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge plus trigger a saving throw (this may already have occurred)
  • For any actors that fail their save, click the  "Entangled - Duration (T)" action
  • For any actors that make their save, click whichever  move action reduces actor current movement by 50% until an actor is free of the AOE
  • If a new actor enters the AOE during the duration, roll saves and apply actions as described above

system.description:
General

Cure light wounds allows the cleric to lay hands upon a wounded creature, restoring [[/roll 1d8]] hit points to the spell's beneficiary.

This spell does not heal disease, reattach limbs, or bring back the dead, nor can it add hit points beyond a character's normal number.

The reverse of this spell is Cause Light Wounds.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

Non-corporeal creatures are not affected by this spell, nor are undead.

actions.name: Cure Light Wounds
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Target the actor to be healed
  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (steps to this point may already have been done)
  • Click on the "Heal 1d8" action to apply it to the target actor

system.description:
[Foundry Note: The description of this spell doesn't specify a damage. If the higher level version Produce Fire does 1d4 damage to many creatures, and passing through ground covered with already-burning oil does 1d6 damage, this feels about right for a single creature taking a fistful of elemental fire direct to the body.  Feel free to adjust if it seems too high. 

While a combat target of the thrown fire doesn't get a save vs the 1d4 damage (if it hits), their gear does proceed straight to item saving throws as described.  While the spell itself doesn't do a tremendous amount of damage, don't overlook that it sets combustibles in the area ablaze.  If cast in a wooden or otherwise dry/flammable area, the resulting natural fire will do damage of its own, as determined by the GM, to any creature remaining within its radius (which may spread!) on succeeding rounds - Ed.]

 

General

On casting this spell, the druid's hand ignites with an eldritch fire that causes no harm to the druid but is otherwise equivalent to the flame of a torch.

The druid may banish the magical flame at will, but fires set by it must be extinguished by normal means.

 

[Foundry Note: use/equip the spell item below as a ranged weapon; set the number in the caster's inventory  the same as the number of rounds duration of the spell for that caster, deleting any excess inventory (if unused) when the duration runs out. - Ed.]

 

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.items.Item.4ycCHxff3fYHfJfz]{Produced Flame}

 

Saves and Other Impediments

There isn't a personal saving throw against the spell's effects.

Combustible gear and materials struck by the fire are entitled to an item saving throw against normal fire.

 

Combat Effects

The flame can be used to set fires and may also be thrown as a missile.

The throwing range of the flame is 40 ft, and when the flame hits an object it will explode, igniting all combustible material in a radius of 15 ft.

actions.name: Produce Flame
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the caster and click the  "Produce Flame - Duration (C)" action
  • Provide the @UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.items.Item.4ycCHxff3fYHfJfz]{Produced Flame} spell item to the caster for the duration of the spell
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the ignition area of effect resulting from thrown flames (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)

system.description:
[Foundry Note: apply both the 1d4 fire damage and 2d4 dmg ongoing effect in round 2 of the spell; there's a 1-round delay before an ongoing effect starts to damage, so applying in round 2 (when inflicting the 1d4 fire damage directly) means the ongoing 2d4 fire damage will kick in in round 3 and run automatically in rounds 3-5.  Then apply the 1d4 fire damage effect again in round 6.- Ed.]

 

General

This extremely powerful spell causes metal to heat up to searing temperatures. The spell inflicts damage and potential side effects.

If none of the mitigations discussed below are available, the target of this spell is well advised to spend a round divesting him- or herself of metal gauntlets and helmet at the very least, to avoid the side effects.

The reverse of this spell is Chill Metal.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

[a common house rule is that countering Heat Metal with Chill Metal, or vice versa, will also negate - Ed.]

There isn't any saving throw against the spell's effects.

Immersion in water will negate the effects of Heat Metal, as will magical protections against fire. 

 

Combat Effects

The effects of continued exposure to the metal as it changes temperature to a damaging level and then returns to normal are set forth below:

Round 1 No effect other than discomfort
Round 2 [[/roll 1d4]] hp damage

Rounds

3-5

 [[/roll 2d4]] hp damage, severe blistering to extremities (hands, feet), and unconsciousness if the metal is a helmet
Round 6 [[/roll 1d4]] hp damage
Round 7 Discomfort

actions.name: Heat Metal
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the actor and click the  "Heat Metal - Duration (T)" action
  • In Round 2 of the spell's duration, target the actor and click both the  "Damage (1d4 Fire)" action and also the  "Ongoing Damage Rds 3-5 (T)" action
  • In Round 6 of the spell's duration, target the actor and click the  "Damage (1d4 Fire)" action

system.areaOfEffect: All metal worn by 1 size M creature per caster level, or 50 lbs weight/level, as applicable

system.description:
General

The powerful enchantment woven by this spell will affect any "person," meaning character races (with the exception of elves) and other small to medium-sized bipeds analogous to persons (orcs, goblins, etc.). The spell also affects mammalian animals of any kind, even those that are supernatural, giant, or monstrous.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

[Foundry Note: it is a common house rule that any damage inflicted by allies of the caster in the same round before the spell is cast, gives an bonus to the saving throw; e.g., if a target took 5 points of damage from an arrow before the spell completed, they would get a saving throw bonus of +5. - Ed.]

The druid must be able to talk to the charmed creature if he or she is to make any sort of complex "request."

Charmed creatures are allowed periodic saving throws to break the charm, based on intelligence:

INT Save Frequency
19+ one saving throw/day
18 one saving throw/2 days
17 one saving throw/3 days
15-16 one saving throw/week
13-14 one saving throw/2 weeks
10-12 one saving throw/3 weeks
7-9 one saving throw/month
4-6 one saving throw/2 months
3 or less one saving throw/3 months

 

The charm will be broken automatically if the druid obviously tries to harm the charmed creature.

 

Combat Effects

If the target creature fails a saving throw, it will view the druid as a trusted friend, interpreting his or her every word in its most positive light.

Charmed creatures will place themselves into moderate danger, including combat, on the druid's behalf, but will not undertake risks beyond those the creature might ordinarily take.

actions.name: Charm Person or Mammal
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Target the enemy actor
  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (these may already have been done) and trigger a saving throw
  • if the saving throw fails click the applicable  "Charmed ?? INT - Duration (T)" action

actionGroups.name: Charm Person or Mammal
actionGroups.description:
General

The powerful enchantment woven by this spell will affect any "person," meaning character races (with the exception of elves) and other small to medium-sized bipeds analogous to persons (orcs, goblins, etc.). The spell also affects mammalian animals of any kind, even those that are supernatural, giant, or monstrous.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

[Foundry Note: it is a common house rule that any damage inflicted by allies of the caster in the same round before the spell is cast, gives an bonus to the saving throw; e.g., if a target took 5 points of damage from an arrow before the spell completed, they would get a saving throw bonus of +5. - Ed.]

The druid must be able to talk to the charmed creature if he or she is to make any sort of complex "request."

Charmed creatures are allowed periodic saving throws to break the charm, based on intelligence:

INT Save Frequency
19+ one saving throw/day
18 one saving throw/2 days
17 one saving throw/3 days
15-16 one saving throw/week
13-14 one saving throw/2 weeks
10-12 one saving throw/3 weeks
7-9 one saving throw/month
4-6 one saving throw/2 months
3 or less one saving throw/3 months

 

The charm will be broken automatically if the druid obviously tries to harm the charmed creature.

 

Combat Effects

If the target creature fails a saving throw, it will view the druid as a trusted friend, interpreting his or her every word in its most positive light.

Charmed creatures will place themselves into moderate danger, including combat, on the druid's behalf, but will not undertake risks beyond those the creature might ordinarily take.

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (these may already have been done) and trigger a saving throw
  • if the saving throw fails click the applicable  "Charmed ?? INT - Duration (T)" action

system.description:
[Foundry Note: To make the touch attack with this spell, use the actor's grappling "weapon" (or other natural weapon if a monster) but instead of rolling grappling damage if successful, enact the spell effect instead. Keep in mind some GMs consider any attack that would have hit AC 10 to be sufficient as a touch spell delivery "hit" - Ed.]

 

General

This spell allows the druid to deliver a lethally poisonous touch.

The reverse of the spell is Neutralize Poison.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

Casting also requires a successful roll to hit, and allows a saving throw against the poison.

actions.name: Poison
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Without applying damage, select the target and use one of the caster's natural attacks (grappling, claw, etc.) as a proxy roll to determine if a touch-attack succeeds
  • with the actor still targeted, click the "Save vrs Poison" action
  • If the touch succeeds, apply the "Poison Death" action to the target actor

system.description:
General

The druid moulds stone by the power of his or her will, shaping it into whatever object or form he or she desires, from a weapon to a sculpture to an ornate stone footstool. Whether used to decorate the druid's grove with statues or to make an escape hole from a stone prison, this spell is extremely versatile and useful.

actionGroups.name: Stone Shape
actionGroups.description:
General

The druid moulds stone by the power of his or her will, shaping it into whatever object or form he or she desires, from a weapon to a sculpture to an ornate stone footstool. Whether used to decorate the druid's grove with statues or to make an escape hole from a stone prison, this spell is extremely versatile and useful.

system.description:
General

The druid may use this spell to confer considerable protection from fire upon another creature, but if he or she casts it upon him- or herself the effects are far greater, conferring temporary invulnerability even to fires of magical nature, such as dragon's breath.

 

Combat Effects

If the spell is cast upon another creature, the recipient gains immunity to normal fire and a saving throw bonus of +4 against fire based attacks. Any damage incurred by fire attacks will also reduced by half.

If the spell is cast upon the druid, he or she becomes completely invulnerable to normal fire and also ignores all damage from magical fire (dragon breath, fireball, etc.) until a total of 12 hp/caster level has been absorbed by the spell, at which time the spell will be dissipated.

actions.name: Protection From Fire
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • If the target is another actor and click the  "Non-Druid Recipient - Duration (T)" action
  • If the target is the caster and click the  "Druid Recipient - Indefinite (C)" action

system.description:
General

A benison similar to Cure Light Wounds, Cure Serious Wounds permits the cleric to lay on hands for [[/roll 2d8+1]] hit points of healing. The spell's limits are otherwise similar to those of Cure Light Wounds. 

The reverse of this spell is Cause Serious Wounds.

REFERENCED TEXT:

This spell does not heal disease, reattach limbs, or bring back the dead, nor can it add hit points beyond a character's normal number. Non-corporeal creatures are not affected by this spell, nor are undead...

actions.name: Cure Serious Wounds
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Target the actor to be healed
  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (steps to this point may already have been done)
  • Click on the  "Heal 2d8+1" action to apply it to the target actor

system.description:
[Foundry Note: an aura has been added, so as to be visible and persistant while a caster moves, to represent the ring effect with a default size of 10' radius.  After it is applied to a caster it can be changed on their details tab to any size up to the stated 5 ft radius/level.

A separate shape effect is given in 20 ft blocks for a caster to detail on a map (in 20 ft chunks) the size of the spell if casting it as a wall. - Ed.]

 

General

One of the more dramatic examples of druidic magic is the wall of fire spell, by which the druid calls up a blazing inferno of flame in the shape of a wall. One side of the conflagration emits the searing heat one would expect, but the other side emits merely a gentle warmth.

The wall persists for as long as the druid concentrates upon it.  [Foundry Note: - concentration precludes movement or any other action.  If the druid desires to move they must stop concentrating to do so. - Ed.]

If the druid does not choose to maintain concentration, it remains for 1 round/caster level.

The druid may evoke a Wall of Fire in one of two shapes.

Straight wall:

  • up to one 20 ft square per caster level arranged as desired
  • a wall is stationary

Ring :

  • radius of up to five ft per caster level (caster in centre)
  • 20 ft high
  • A ring moves with the caster

 

Saves and Other Impediments

No saving throws are allowed to avoid or reduce taken from the wall.

 

Combat Effects

Passing through the flames inflicts [[/roll 4d4]] damage plus 1/caster level.  Additionally:

  • Creatures as far as 10 ft from the hot side incur [[/roll 2d4]] hit points of damage.
  • Creatures between 10 and 20 ft from the hot side incur [[/roll 1d4]] points of damage.

Undead creatures suffer worse from the power of this druidic magic, taking twice the ordinary damage the wall would inflict.

actions.name: Wall of Fire
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • (Optional) to visualize a ring casting, target the caster and click the  "Ring Aura - (C)" action, which has no mechanical function but provides a visual indication of the AOE which moves with the caster
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize a wall casting's area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
    • As the AOE can be shaped within reason to the caster's desire, the castshape provides individual 20x20 "blocks" of AOE which may be built into a specific final AOE by re-clicking the action and placing more blocks
  • If the caster stops concentrating (to move or attack, for example) target the caster and click the  "WOF Post-Concentration - Duration (C)" action to start the finite duration
  • If an undead actor interacts with the ring/wall, apply damage as follows:
    • if the undead actor is between 11 and 20 feet from the wall, target it and click the  "Damage (Proximity 2d4 Fire)" action
    • if the undead actor is between 1 and 10 feet from the wall, target it and click the  "Damage (Proximity 4d4 Fire)" action
    • If the undead actor contacts the wall, target it and click the  "Undead Wall Touch" action
  • If any other actor interacts with the ring/wall, apply damage as follows:
    • if the actor is between 11 and 20 feet from the wall, target it and click the  "Damage (Proximity 1d4 Fire)" action
    • if the actor is between 1 and 10 feet from the wall, target it and click the  "Damage (Proximity 2d4 Fire)" action
    • If the actor contacts the wall, target it and click the  "Wall Touch" action

  • If the caster stops concentrating (to move or attack, for example) target the caster and click the  "WOF Post-Concentration - Duration (C)" action to start the finite duration
  • If an undead actor interacts with the ring/wall, apply damage as follows:
    • if the undead actor is between 11 and 20 feet from the wall, target it and click the  "Damage (Proximity 2d4 Fire)" action
    • if the undead actor is between 1 and 10 feet from the wall, target it and click the  "Damage (Proximity 4d4 Fire)" action
    • If the undead actor contacts the wall, target it and click the  "Undead Wall Touch" action
  • If any other actor interacts with the ring/wall, apply damage as follows:
    • if the actor is between 11 and 20 feet from the wall, target it and click the  "Damage (Proximity 1d4 Fire)" action
    • if the actor is between 1 and 10 feet from the wall, target it and click the  "Damage (Proximity 2d4 Fire)" action
    • If the actor contacts the wall, target it and click the  "Wall Touch" action

system.description:
General

It is within the power of a high-level druid to summon forth an elemental being from the plane of fire. The elemental will ordinarily be of 16 HD, but there is a 5% chance that it will be of 24 HD and a 1% chance that an afreet, rather than an elemental, will appear.

 

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.MHkTz0E8LixRu9r0]{Conjure Fire Elemental (Druidic) Result}

 

Druids need no protective circle to summon fire elementals and need not concentrate upon the elemental in any way.

 

Combat Effects

The elemental will act as the druid's ally, remaining for the spell's duration to assist him or her however possible, including engaging in combat with his or her enemies.

actions.name: Conjure Fire Elemental
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • When summoned, roll on the table @UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.MHkTz0E8LixRu9r0]{Conjure Fire Elemental (Druidic) Result} and add the indicated token to the scene and customize it as described in the spell description
  • Add Fire Elemental token to the combat tracker - this is necessary for the automatic token death to work
  • Apply  "Fire Elemental - Duration Autokill" effect to the Fire Elemental's token on the map
  • The GM can trigger attacks through the attacks/actions on the token

biography.value: A mysterious traveler from the lands east of Greyhawk, Kerrak the druid communes with the forces of nature to right wrongs while putting a little gold in his pocket along the way.

system.description:
General

Humans are the standard for the game, and as such, humans have no unusual abilities or limitations in game terms. Because of their potential for unlimited progression in all the character classes save assassin and druid, humans are a popular choice for most players. This is an intentional feature of the rules.

A common house rule in OSRIC-compatible games is the adjustment or removal of demi-human level limits. This will unbalance the game in favour of demi-humans unless humans are given some corresponding advantage. GMs considering such a house rule for their own OSRIC-compatible games are advised to ensure that in most campaigns, humans should still represent an attractive choice for their players.

 

Movement Rate: 120 ft

 

Starting Age:

Cleric [[/roll 20+1d4]]
Fighter [[/roll 15+1d4]]
Mage [[/roll 24+2d8]]
Thief [[/roll 20+1d4]]

[Foundry Note: sub-classes are as main class. - Ed.]

 

Level Limitations:

Assassin 15
Cleric Unlimited
Druid 14
Fighter Unlimited
Illusionist Unlimited
Magic User Unlimited
Paladin Unlimited
Ranger Unlimited
Thief Unlimited

[Foundry Note:  This "weapon" is included in the non-lethal skill bundle and doesn't require a separate drop on an actor sheet. 

All characters can put this "weapon" in their inventory just as they would a dagger, etc.   All characters are proficient in all forms of unarmed combat without spending weapon proficiences; attach the like-named proficiency that comes with all classes to the weapon without having to spend any points.]

Unarmed combat: Brawling attacks, such as those conducted with fist, foot, or dagger pommel, will normally inflict [[/roll 1d2]] points of damage.

[ Note: All characters can put this "weapon" in their inventory just as they would a dagger, etc.   All characters are proficient in all forms of unarmed combat without spending weapon proficiences; attach the like-named proficiency that comes with all classes to the weapon without having to spend any points.]

Unarmed combat - grapple: A successful grappling attack inflicts 0-1 ([[/roll 1d2-1]]) points of damage, but also restrains the target and prevents him or her from fighting. The chance of breaking a successful grapple should be determined according to the relative strengths of the creatures concerned. (An ogre could restrain a kobold almost indefinitely, and would be able to break free of the kobold's grasp at will.)

Unarmed combat - overbearing: Overbearing attacks are Grappling attacks exercised at the end of a Charge (see "Charge" above). If successful, the opponent is prone rather than restrained. Otherwise the attack is treated as a grapple.

Referenced Text: A successful grappling attack inflicts 0-1 ([[/roll 1d2-1]]) points of damage, but also restrains the target and prevents him or her from fighting. The chance of breaking a successful grapple should be determined according to the relative strengths of the creatures concerned. (An ogre could restrain a kobold almost indefinitely, and would be able to break free of the kobold's grasp at will.)

Referenced Text: Charge: Charging into combat allows the attacker to move and then attack in the same round. A charge is made at twice the normal movement rate (and must terminate within the 10-ft melee range of the target). If the defender has a longer weapon than the attacker, the defender attacks first (unless the defender has already acted in this round). The attacker gains no dexterity bonus against such an attack (and characters with no dexterity bonus receive a +1 AC penalty). Additionally, if the defender has a weapon set against the charge (see below), he or she will inflict additional damage with a successful hit against the charging attacker.

Assuming that the charging character survives, he or she gains +2 "to hit" on his or her attack. Characters may only perform a charge once every 10 rounds (i.e. once per turn). Characters who are at the maximum encumbrance category may not charge unless they are mounted and the mount is below the maximum encumbrance category.

system.description:
Thieves and assassins have an enhanced chance to hear noise as they gain levels (see “thief skills” in Chapter I). Characters of all other classes have a base 10% chance. This should be modified by race; elves, gnomes, halflings, and half-orcs have a base 15% chance.  (In Foundry, these races have a 5% bonus added to their skill check target number automatically when the skill is used- Ed.)

 

Hear - Base Chance/Target Formula

Assassin Thief
Level  Target Range Level Target Range
1 10% 1 10%
2 10% 2 13%
3 10% 3 16%
4 13% 4 19%
5 16% 5 22%
6 19% 6 25%
7 22% 7 28%
8 25% 8 31%
9 28% 9 34%
10 31% 10 37%
11 34% 11 40%
12 37% 12 43%
13 40% 13 46%
14 43% 14 49%
15 46% 15 52%
    16 55%
    17 58%
    18 61%
    19 64%
    20 67%
    21 70%
    22 73%
    23 76%
    24 79%

 

Normally the GM rolls this die in secret, because the player has no way of knowing whether no noise was heard because of the roll or because there was no noise to hear. A character who fails (or thinks he or she has failed) to hear noise may try again, each attempt taking one round. However, no more than three attempts may be made the same character before the strain becomes too great and no further listening attempts will succeed until the character has rested for at least one turn.

If the check is successful, the GM should decide whether there is in fact any noise to be heard. Some monsters, such as bugbears, are stealthy and cannot be detected by listening. However, generally if there is some monster in the area and a “hear noise” check is passed, the party should gain some clue about what it is. Clever players whose characters speak various monster languages may gain valuable information from overhearing snatches of conversation—but the GM should be careful only to describe what characters can actually hear. So the GM would not normally say “you hear a giant spider,” but rather “you hear a scuttling, rattling sound” as the creature climbs to a suitable spot from which to ambush the party.

Don’t forget, monsters can hear the party in the same way as the party can hear them!
system.dmonlytext:
Listening for noise as often as possible, at every door and intersection, is an understandably common tactic, because it’s one of the easiest ways for players to improve the odds in their favour — so as to be able to make better-informed decisions about their actions. This is fine in moderation. However, if the pace of play slows considerably, diminishing the excitement and reducing the adventure to dice-rolling, the GM should discourage the players from endless listening attempts. Emphasise the inconvenience of donning and doffing helmets and headgear while the rest of the party stands around doing nothing; and if play is still slow, employ tricks that circumvent listening, e.g. silent monsters or phantom noises (perhaps due to strange acoustics in the dungeon or magic). In extreme cases the GM can place traps and monsters that specifically target listening characters, but before it gets to that, the GM should speak frankly to the players and explain that while some degree of caution is good play, carrying things to extremes only makes the game less fun.

Balance this against the lethality of the dungeon. In extremely dangerous areas, the players should not be punished for taking due care.

system.description: This is used to determine success on minor feats of strength such as forcing a dungeon door that doesn't open easily (this is the average dungeon door).
This is used to attempt an extraordinary success on minor feats of strength such as forcing a dungeon door enspelled by minor magics such as Hold Portal or Wizard Lock.
[Foundry Note: your GM likely will require this skill to be rolled as GM private. - Ed.]

General

Druids worship the spiritual power of nature, maintain and protect holy places, perform festivals and ritual observances, and protect balance and harmony between civilisation and nature. Their magic is rooted in the mystical oneness of nature, and they have particular power over fire, stone, and weather, as well as over plant- and animal life.

Some druids pay homage to particular nature gods (some of these quite savage), while others eschew all deities and commune directly with the spiritual power of nature.

Rather than using a holy symbol as clerics do, druids require mistletoe, holly, or (if neither can be found) oak leaves to cast their spells, and one of these is a required component for all druidic spells unless a druidic spell has no material component specified in the spell description.

The druid must harvest these materials by the light of a full moon, or the darkness of a new moon, in order for the component to work with full efficacy. If mistletoe or holly is not gathered by the druid's hand at the proper time, the druid's spells will have only half the normal effect.

Oak leaves always produce spells of half power, and if they are not harvested properly, oak leaves will permit spells of only one-quarter power.

Player character druids must be neutral, although druids of differing alignments may be found as non-player characters in some GMs' campaigns.

Druids receive bonus spells for high wisdom, just as clerics do. See the table provided under "Cleric" for details.

There can only be a certain number of high-level druids in the world. The limits are: 12th level druid (High Druid) - no more than 3 in the world at any one time; 13th level druid(Archdruid) - no more than 2 in the world at any given time, 14th level druid (Supreme Druid) - no more than a single Supreme Druid can exist.

If a druid receives so many experience points that he or she is eligible to increase to these levels, but all the vacant slots are already filled, then he or she must create a vacancy. This is done by issuing a formal challenge to the druid in question, following which the two characters must compete in a contest of some kind - often, but not necessarily, a duel.

The loser of the contest goes down to the next lowest level (losing all experience down to the very minimum to qualify for the new level). This may, in turn, result in a further contest if the preceding level is also fully occupied.

 

Minimum Scores: Str 6, Dex 6, Con 6, Int 6, Wis 12, Cha 15

 

Hit Die Type: d8 (max 14)

 

Alignment: Neutral only

 

Experience bonus: Wisdom and Charisma 16+

 

Armour/Shield Permitted: Leather only, wooden shields only

 

Weapons Permitted: Club, dagger, dart, hammer, oil, scimitar, sling, spear, staff

 

Weapon Proficiencies: 2, +1 every 3 levels

 

Penalty to hit for non-proficiency: -4

 

Weapon Specialisation: N/A

 

Druid Class Abilities

Druids' Cant: All druids speak a secret language called the druids' cant. The druidic cant cannot be learned by non-druids (unless otherwise noted, such as in the case of higher-level assassins).

 

Saving Throw Bonus: All druids gain a saving throw bonus of +2 against fire and lightning attacks of all kinds.

 

Spell Casting: Druids may memorise and cast druidic spells in accordance with the tables provided below.

 

Druid's Knowledge (3rd): At third level and higher, a druid can identify plant and animal types, and can determine when water is pure and safe to drink.

 

Wilderness Movement (3rd): At third level and higher, a druid can move through any natural undergrowth leaving no trace of his or her passage, and may do so with no reduction in his or her normal movement speed.

 

Immunity to Fey Charm (7th): At seventh level and higher, the druid becomes immune to charms and other such mental enchantments cast by fey creatures such as dryads, pixies, brownies, etc.

 

Shapeshift (7th): Druids of 7th level or higher may change their forms up to three times per day. The form assumed must be a natural animal, no smaller than a mouse, and no larger than double the druid's normal weight; in the process of shapeshifting, the druid recovers 1d6 x 10 percent of any hit points he or she might have sustained as damage.

 

Perceive Magical Surveillance (7th): [Foundry Note: the inclusion of this skill is a Foundry-specific addition.  Also please note that the specific target number for this skill is determined both by level and INT score, so 7th is simply the earliest level a druid could possibly emply it.  See the skill description to determine the specific target number for any actor. If current level/INT doesn't qualify an actor to use the skill, set the target number to "0" until the actor does qualify. The target number likely requires adjustment in any case as levels are gained. - Ed.]

actions.description:
Type: Divine

School: Transmutation/Alteration

Sphere: Druidic

Level: 2

Cast Time: 4 segments

Range: Caster

Duration: 2 rounds/level

Save: See below

AOE: See below

Components: VSM

[Foundry Note: The description of this spell doesn't specify a damage. If the higher level version Produce Fire does 1d4 damage to many creatures, and passing through ground covered with already-burning oil does 1d6 damage, this feels about right for a single creature taking a fistful of elemental fire direct to the body.  Feel free to adjust if it seems too high. 

While a combat target of the thrown fire doesn't get a save vs the 1d4 damage (if it hits), their gear does proceed straight to item saving throws as described.  While the spell itself doesn't do a tremendous amount of damage, don't overlook that it sets combustibles in the area ablaze.  If cast in a wooden or otherwise dry/flammable area, the resulting natural fire will do damage of its own, as determined by the GM, to any creature remaining within its radius (which may spread!) on succeeding rounds - Ed.]

 

General

On casting this spell, the druid's hand ignites with an eldritch fire that causes no harm to the druid but is otherwise equivalent to the flame of a torch.

The druid may banish the magical flame at will, but fires set by it must be extinguished by normal means.

 

[Foundry Note: use the spell item below as a ranged weapon; set the number in inventory as the same as the number of rounds duration, deleting any excess when the duration runs out. - Ed.]

 

@UUID[Item.4ycCHxff3fYHfJfz]{Produced Flame}

 

Saves and Other Impediments

There isn't a personal saving throw against the spell's effects.

Combustible gear and materials struck by the fire are entitled to an item saving throw against normal fire.

 

Combat Effects

The flame can be used to set fires and may also be thrown as a missile.

The throwing range of the flame is 40 ft, and when the flame hits an object it will explode, igniting all combustible material in a radius of 15 ft.

All druids gain a saving throw bonus of +2 against fire and lightning attacks of all kinds.

Use this Proficiency to negate the penalty the system would otherwise apply to any spell items used in conjunction with various spells.  This is done by adding the spell items to this proficiency before they're used in combat. 

Example spell items are:

 

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.items.Item.ocld9MsdB0PV6LPE]{Fire Seed (Acorn)}

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.items.Item.pvVoXWKNrUdSgq9t]{Fire Seed (Holly)}

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.items.Item.4ycCHxff3fYHfJfz]{Produced Flame}

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.items.Item.T8eNorBXy2DYK5yz]{Shillelagh}

 

Other spell items may be created by  the GM, or a player through spell research.

[Foundry Note: if deleting the type of "Shape Changer" from the druid class item when PC actors are less than 7th level, the GM should re-add that type on to the class item now so that various magic items interact with a druid as the rule set presumes. - Ed.]

actionGroups.name: Shapeshift
actionGroups.description:
[Foundry Note: if deleting the type of "Shape Changer" from the druid class item when PC actors are less than 7th level, the GM should re-add that type on to the class item now so that various magic items interact with a druid as the rule set presumes. - Ed.]

 

Druids of 7th level or higher may change their forms up to three times per day. The form assumed must be a natural animal, no smaller than a mouse, and no larger than double the druid's normal weight; in the process of shapeshifting, the druid recovers 1d6 x 10 percent of any hit points he or she might have sustained as damage.

system.description:
Magic users of 7th or higher level may create magical potions, scribe arcane scrolls (of spells that he or she already knows) and recharge magical rods, staves and wands.  Magic users are the only class capable of fabricating magic items that they cannot themselves employ.

Clerics, druids, and illusionists of 7th or higher level also have this ability, limited to items they can use (although other classes may use this item also).  An illusionist, for example, could create a potion of healing but not a potion of heroism.

This is a passive chance for some actors or monsters that use spells or spell-like actions, and which also are some combination of powerful and intelligent to notice when someone attempts to surveill them magically by spell (Clairvoyance, Clairaudience, ESP, etc.) or magic items (Crystal Ball, etc.).

 

An approximate table for use in assigning detection features is below - it is not "cut and dried" and the GM should always use this as a guideline only, assigning the value felt appropriate if an individual has some unique quality (and/or increasing the chance if an individual gains in power or intelligence over time).

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.LkUCtqcIYSzHjPAZ]{Potions/Oils/Elixers - Onset Time After Use}

[Foundry Note: the half-drink aspect of potions is handled by giving potions 2 charges, so that half drinks can cost 1 charge and register against the total.  Going this route means the "empty" potion item will need to be manually deleted from inventory once all charges are used, however. 

It is suggested a character benefitting from potions of longevity record the cumulative age reversed, in case it's all reapplied.  Also, there is no "half-drink" for this potion. - Ed.]

 

Allowed Classes

Any

 

General

This potion makes the drinker [[/roll 1d12]] years younger. This restored youth is possible not only for natural ageing, but also for ageing from magic or creature effects.

There is some small danger however, since each time a potion of longevity is consumed there is a cumulative 1% probability that all previous age reversals from potions of this type will be negated, raising the character's age to the age he or she would be without the effects of the potions.

It is not possible to drink this potion in increments.
system.dmonlytext:
GPV: 1,000gp

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables-gm.RollTable.rwszf5JfBY1KgHyE]{Potion - Admixture Results}

(Foundry Note: the admixture rule is intended for use with potions that persist concurrently in the body.  It is suggested that potions which apply their benefit and then do not persist (and can't be dispelled) were not intended to be used with that table, as the context of  "permanent" table results makes evident.  However the materials are silent on this point and as such each GM may determine differently - Ed.)

system.description: Capacity: 4 cu. ft. or 40 lbs

Allowed Classes

Any

 

Boots (General)

Note regarding magic footwear: These items will magically resize to fit any player character class from the OSRIC core rulebook, unless otherwise noted in the item description. The rule of thumb for size limitation is: halfling size at the small end and the very largest of humans at the other. As always, however, this may not apply in your campaign at your GM’s discretion. In all cases, both boots must be worn before any magical effect takes place.

 

Details

Allow the user to levitate or descend up to 20 ft per round, no limit on usage. These boots are not capable of lifting a total weight of more than about 600 lbs. Aerial agility level is only I.

actions.description:
Type: Arcane

School: Transmutation/Alteration

Sphere: MU

Level: 2

Cast Time: 0

Range: 60 ft

Duration: 6 turns

Save: Negates

AOE: Caster (600 lbs total possible weight)

Components: V

 

General

This scroll allows the magic user to levitate him- or herself or another person.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell may be cast upon an unwilling enemy, but in this case the intended target is entitled to a saving throw.

The maximum weight which can be affected with this scroll is 600 lbs.

The spell does not allow any sort of horizontal movement (aerial agility level I - see Chapter III), but it is possible for a levitated person to pull him- or herself along if there is something upon which to gain purchase, such as a wall.

 

Combat Effects

The magic user can move vertically up or down at a rate of 20 ft per round, and can levitate another at a rate of 10 ft per round.
actions.name: Levitate
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done).
  • Target the caster and click the "Levitate - Duration (C)" action

Details

Shields do NOT affect armour class where the target is being attacked from the rear.

Likewise, a figure attacked by several opponents may only employ the shield against a limited number of attacks per round:

  • one attack/round (small shield)
  • two attacks/round (medium shield)
  • three attacks/round (large shield)

Thus AC against multiple opponents will tend to deteriorate.

system.description:
[Foundry Note: This is a Container-item that can be used on a character sheet to hold items carried on the horse (switch their status to "not carried" so their weight doesn't accumulate on the PC or NPC actor).  If the animal is needed for combat purposes, the actor linked below can be pulled on to the map/combat tracker with stats adjusted as appropriate. - Ed.]

 

In 1st Edition AD&D, according to the Monster Manual (1977), a hippogriff can carry approximately 500 pounds maximum weight, including rider and gear.

Details (Monster Manual, p. 53):

  • A hippogriff is described as having a maximum load limit of 500 lbs.

  • The creature itself typically weighs around 1,000 lbs.

  • They can comfortably carry a rider wearing armor and additional equipment, provided the total load doesn't exceed their 500 lb capacity.

Details

When donned, this ring grants the wearer the ability to become instantly invisible at will as per the 2nd level magic user spell. Attacking while invisible negates invisibility.
system.dmonlytext:
XP/GP Value

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables-gm.RollTable.bhTLYvZJqwDj6qZA]{Magic Ring-as-Jewellery Value}

 

Apparent (Jewellery) Value: ?

(True) GPV: 7,500 gp

 

General (Ring)

Magic rings appear indistinguishable from ordinary finger jewellery of varying types, though a Detect Magic spell cast upon them will cause them to radiate a magic aura. With the exception of a wish spell, the only way to determine the function of a magic ring is to put it on.

A maximum of two rings can be worn by any PC or NPC at a time; only one ring may be worn per hand. Attempting to wear additional magic rings will render all worn magical rings useless. Magic rings worn on toes or as earrings will not function.

Unless noted otherwise, the abilities a ring grants function as if cast by a 12th level spell caster, or the minimum level required to cast the spell if greater than 12th.

Because of the innate magical resistance of dwarfs, gnomes, and halflings; magic rings have a 20% chance per use of not working at all and, if cursed, the curse will fail. In such a case the wearer recognises the cursed properties of the ring and can easily remove it from his or her finger.

actions.name: Invisibility
actions.description:
Type: Arcane

School: Illusion/Phantasm

Sphere: MU

Level: 2

Cast Time: 2

Range: Touch

Duration: See below

Save: None

AOE: One creature

Components: VSM

General

When the words of this spell are completed, the recipient and all he or she carries fade from sight, becoming invisible.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell remains in effect until the invisible creature attacks someone, the caster ends the spell, or the magic is dispelled. Note that the spell does not make the recipient any more quiet than normal, nor does it eliminate scents.

The invisible person can see him- or herself, but the caster (unless they are one and the same) cannot.

The spell cannot be cast upon an unwilling subject.

 

Combat Effects

Invisible opponent: An invisible opponent can only be attacked if the general location is known, and the attack is at –4 to hit.  

Even infravision cannot detect an invisible creature.

If an opponent is invisible to the attacker, he or she cannot be attacked from behind (or from the flank).

Note that more powerful monsters (those with sensitive smell or hearing, or more than six hit dice) will frequently be able to detect invisible opponents; the GM should determine the chance of this according to the creature concerned and the situation.

Powerful magical monsters, or those with more than 11 hit dice, will almost always be able to see invisible creatures normally.
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the ring wearer and click the "Invisible - Indefinite (T)" action
    • If the invisible actor makes an attack the invisibility is immediately deleted by the GM

system.description:
Healing A character proficient in healing
knows how to use natural medicines and
basic principles of first aid and doctoring. If
the character tends another within one
round of wounding (and makes a successful
proficiency check), his ministrations restore
Id3 hit points (but no more hit points can be
restored than were lost in the previous
round). Only one healing attempt can be
made on a character per day.
If a wounded character remains under the
care of someone with healing proficiency,
that character can recover lost hit points at
the rate of 1 per day even when traveling or
engaging in nonstrenuous activity. If the
wounded character gets complete rest, he
can recover 2 hit points per day while under
such care. M y characters with both heal-
ing and herbalism proficiencies can help
others recover at the rate of 3 hit points per
day of rest. This care does not require a pro-
ficiency check, only the regular attention of
the proficient character. Up to six patients
can be cared for at any time.
A character with healing proficiency can
also attempt to aid a poisoned individual,
provided the poison entered through a
wound. If the poisoned character can be
tended to immediately (the round after the
character is poisoned) and the care con-
tinues for the next five rounds, the victim
gains a +2 bonus to his saving throw (delay
his saving throw until the last round of tend-
ing). No proficiency check is required, but
the poisoned character must be tended to
immediately (normally by sacrificing any
other action by the proficient character) and
cannot do anything himself. If the care and
rest are interrupted, the poisoned character
must immediately roll a normal saving
throw for the poison. This result is unalter-
able by normal means (Le., more healing
doesn't help). Only characters with both
healing and herbalism proficiencies can
attempt the same treatment for poisons the
victim has swallowed or touched (the char-
acter uses his healing to diagnose the poison
and his herbalist knowledge to prepare a
purgative).
A character with healing proficiency can
also attempt to diagnose and treat diseases.
When dealing with normal diseases, a suc-
cessful proficiency check automatically
reduces the disease to its mildest form and
shortest duration. Those who also have her-
balism knowledge gain an additional +2
bonus to this check. A proficient character
can also attempt to deal with magical dis-
eases, whether caused by spells or creatures.
In this case, a successful proficiency check
diagnoses the cause of the disease. How-
ever, since the disease is magical in nature, it
can be treated only by magical means.

Animal Handling: Proficiency in this area
enables a character to exercise a greater-
than-normal degree of control over pack
animals and beasts of burden. A successful
proficiency check indicates that the charac-
ter has succeeded in calming an excited or
agitated animal; in contrast, a character
without this proficiency has only a 20%
chance of succeeding in the attempt.

Aninul Training: Characters with this
proficiency can train one type of creature
(declared when the proficiency is chosen) to
obey simple commands and perform tricks.
A character can spend additional proficien-
cis to train other types of creatures or can
improve his skill with an already chosen
type. Creatures typically trained are dogs,
horses, falcons, pigeons, elephants, ferrets,
and parrots. A character can choose even
more exotic creatures and monsters with
cult to control).
A trainer can woik with up to three crea-
tures at onetime. The trainer may choose to
teach general tasks or specific tricks. A gen-
eral task gives the creature the ability to
react to a number of nonqxdic commands
to do its job. Examples of tasks include
guard and attack, carry a rider, perform
heavy labor, hunt, track, or fight alongside
soldiers (such as a war horse or elephant).A
specific trick teaches the trained creature to
do one specific action. A horse may rear on
command, a falcon may pluck a designated
object, a dog may attack a specific person,
or a rat may run through a particular maze.
With enough time, a creature can be trained
-to do both general tasks and specific tricks.
Training for a general task requires three
months of uninterrupted work. Training for
a specific trick requires 2d6 weeks. At the
end of the training time, a proficiency check
is made. If successful, the animal is trained.
If the die roll fails, the beast is untrainable.
An animal can be trained in 2d4 general
tasks or specific tricks, or any combination
of thetwo.
An animal trainer can also try to tame
wild animals (preparing them for training
later on). Wild animals can be tamed only
when they are very young. The taming
requires one month of uninterrupted work
with the creature. At the end of the month, a
proficiency check is made. If successful, the
beast is suitable for training. If the check
fails, the creature retains enough of its wild
behavior to make it untrainable. It can be
kept, though it must be leashed or caged.

Navigation: The character has learned the
arts of navigating by the stars, studying cur-
rents, and watching for telltale signs of
land, reefs, and hidden danger. This is not
particularly useful on land. At sea, a suc-
cessful proficiency check by the navigator
reduces the chance of getting lost by 20 per-
cent.

Spellcraft: Although this proficiency does
not grant the character any spellcasting
powers, it does give him familiarity-with the
different forms and rites of spellcasting. If
he observes and overhears someone who is
casting a spell, or if he examines the material
components used, he can attempt to identify
the spell being cast. A proficiency check
must be rolIed to make a correct idendifica-
tion. Wizard specialists spin a +3 bonus to
the check when attempting to identify magic
of their own school. Note that since the
spellcaster must be observed until the my
instant of casting, the spellcraft proficiency
does not grant an advantage against combat
spells. The proficiency is quite useful, how-
ever, for identifying spells that would other-
wise have no visible effect.
Those talented in this proficiency also
have a chance (equal to 1/2 of their
proficiency check) of recognizing magical) or
magically endowed constructs for what
they are.

[Foundry Note: see the spell item "Shillelagh".  The druid gains the item for the duration of the spell to use in combat. All druids start with a free weapon proficiency called "Spell Items"  which they can pair with this item so that they don't inadvertently suffer non-proficiency penalties when using this spell. 

Although a range of "touch" normally means the caster need not be the recipient of the spell, here it refers to touching what is essentially the material component of the spell - the club/billet. - Ed.]

 

General

The druid imbues a club or billet of oak-wood with enchanted power. The shillelagh must be wielded by the druid in order for it to possess these magical properties; in the hands of any other person it will be no more than an ordinary wooden club.

 

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.items.Item.T8eNorBXy2DYK5yz]{Shillelagh}

 

Combat Effects

The shillelagh is +2 to hit and capable of inflicting [[/roll 2d6]] points of damage against small and medium-sized opponents, [[/roll 1d6+1]] against large opponents.
